document.title:
Bernstein’s inequality and Nikolsky’s inequality for
R d

section.title: 1Complex Borel measures and the Fourier transform

para.p:
Let
=
⁢ M
(
R d
)
⁢ r c a
(
R d
)
be the set of complex Borel measures on
R d
. This is a Banach algebra with the total variation norm, with convolution as multiplication; for
∈ μ
⁢ M
(
R d
)
, we denote by
| μ |
the total variation of
μ
, which itself belongs to
⁢ M
(
R d
)
, and the total variation norm of
μ
is
=
∥ μ ∥
⁢
| μ |
(
R d
)
.

For
∈ μ
⁢ M
(
R d
)
, it is a fact that the union
O
of all open sets
⊂ U
R d
such that
=
⁢
| μ |
( U )
0
itself satisfies
=
⁢
| μ |
( O )
0
. We define
=
⁢ supp μ
∖
R d
O
, called the support of
μ
.

For
∈ μ
⁢ M
(
R d
)
, we define
:
^ μ
→
R d
C
by

Math.text: formulae@(hat@(mu) * xi = (integral _ (R ^ d))@(e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * xi) cdot x) * differential-d@(mu) * x), xi element-of R ^ d)

para.p:
It is a fact that
^ μ
belongs to
⁢
C u
( R )
, the collection of bounded uniformly continuous functions
→
R d
C
. For
∈ ξ
R d
,

Math.text: absolute-value@(hat@(mu) * xi) less= (integral _ (R ^ d))@(absolute-value@(e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * xi) cdot x)) * d * absolute-value@(mu) * x) = absolute-value@(mu) * R ^ d = norm@(mu)

para.p:
Let
m d
be Lebesgue measure on
R d
. For
∈ f
⁢
L 1
(
R d
)
, let

Math.text: Lambda _ f = f * m _ d

para.p:
which belongs to
⁢ M
(
R d
)
. We define
:
^ f
→
R d
C
by

Math.text: formulae@(hat@(f) * xi = widehat@(Lambda _ f) * xi = (integral _ (R ^ d))@(e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * xi) cdot x) * differential-d@(Lambda _ f) * x) = (integral _ (R ^ d))@(f * x * e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * xi) cdot x) * differential-d@(m _ d) * x), xi element-of R ^ d)

para.p: The following theorem establishes properties of the Fourier transform of a complex Borel measure with compact support. 1 1 footnote 1 Thomas H. Wolff, Lectures on Harmonic Analysis, p. 3, Proposition 1.3.

p.text:
If
∈ μ
⁢ M
(
R d
)
and
⁢ supp μ
is compact, then
∈
^ μ
⁢
C ∞
(
R d
)
and for any multi-index
α
,

Math.text: D ^ alpha * hat@(mu) = F * (- 2 * pi * i * x) ^ alpha * mu

p.text:
For
> R 0
, if
⊂
⁢ supp μ
¯
⁢ B
( 0 , R )
, then

Math.text: (norm@(D ^ alpha * hat@(mu))) _ infinity less= (2 * pi * R) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * norm@(mu)

para.p:
For
= j
1 , … , d
, let
e j
be the
j
th coordinate vector in
R d
, with length 1. Let
∈ ξ
R d
, and define

Math.text: formulae@(Delta * h = (hat@(mu) * (xi + h * e _ j) - hat@(mu) * xi) / h, h not-equals 0)

para.p: We can write this as

Math.text: Delta * h = (integral _ (R ^ d))@(((e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * h * x _ j) - 1) / h) * e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * xi) cdot x) * differential-d@(mu) * x)

para.p:
For any
∈ x
R d
,

Math.text: absolute-value@((e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * h * x _ j) - 1) / h) = absolute-value@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * h * x _ j) - 1) / absolute-value@(h) less= absolute-value@(- 2 * pi * i * h * x _ j) / absolute-value@(h) = 2 * pi * absolute-value@(x _ j)

para.p:
Because
μ
has compact support,
∈
⁢ 2 π
|
x j
|
⁢
L 1
( μ )
. Furthermore, for each
∈ x
R d
we have

Math.text: formulae@((e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * h * x _ j) - 1) / h to - 2 * pi * i * x _ j, h to 0)

para.p: Therefore, the dominated convergence theorem tells us that

Math.text: (limit _ (h to 0))@(Delta * h) = integral _ (R ^ d) - 2 * pi * i * x _ j * e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * xi) cdot x) * d * mu * x

para.p:
On the other hand, for
=
α k
1
for
= k j
and
=
α k
0
otherwise,

Math.text: D ^ alpha * hat@(mu) * xi = (limit _ (h to 0))@(Delta * h)

para.p: so

Math.text: D ^ alpha * hat@(mu) * xi = (integral _ (R ^ d))@((- 2 * pi * i * x) ^ alpha * e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * xi) cdot x) * differential-d@(mu) * x) = F * (- 2 * pi * i * x) ^ alpha * mu * xi

para.p:
and in particular,
∈
^ μ
⁢
C 1
(
R d
)
. (The Fourier transform of a regular complex Borel measure on a locally compact abelian group is bounded and uniformly continuous. 2 2 footnote 2 Walter Rudin, Fourier Analysis on Groups, p. 15, Theorem 1.3.3.) Because
μ
has compact support so does
⁢
(
-
⁢ 2 π i x
)
α
μ
, hence we can play the above game with
⁢
(
-
⁢ 2 π i x
)
α
μ
, and by induction it follows that for any
α
,

Math.text: D ^ alpha * hat@(mu) = F * (- 2 * pi * i * x) ^ alpha * mu

para.p:
and in particular,
∈
^ μ
⁢
C ∞
(
R d
)
.

Suppose that
⊂
⁢ supp μ
¯
⁢ B
( 0 , R )
. The total variation of the complex measure
⁢
(
-
⁢ 2 π i x
)
α
μ
is the positive measure

Math.text: (2 * pi) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * (absolute-value@(x _ 1)) ^ (alpha _ 1) * cdots * (absolute-value@(x _ d)) ^ (alpha _ d) * absolute-value@(mu)

para.p: hence

Math.text: norm@((- 2 * pi * i * x) ^ alpha * mu) = (2 * pi) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * (integral _ (R ^ d))@((absolute-value@(x _ 1)) ^ (alpha _ 1) * cdots * (absolute-value@(x _ d)) ^ (alpha _ d) * d * absolute-value@(mu) * x)
norm@((- 2 * pi * i * x) ^ alpha * mu)
absent = (2 * pi) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * (integral _ (R ^ d))@((absolute-value@(x _ 1)) ^ (alpha _ 1) * cdots * (absolute-value@(x _ d)) ^ (alpha _ d) * d * absolute-value@(mu) * x)

absent = (2 * pi) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * (integral _ (overline@(B * open-interval@(0, R))))@((absolute-value@(x _ 1)) ^ (alpha _ 1) * cdots * (absolute-value@(x _ d)) ^ (alpha _ d) * d * absolute-value@(mu) * x)

absent = (2 * pi) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * (integral _ (overline@(B * open-interval@(0, R))))@((absolute-value@(x _ 1)) ^ (alpha _ 1) * cdots * (absolute-value@(x _ d)) ^ (alpha _ d) * d * absolute-value@(mu) * x)
absent less= (2 * pi) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * (integral _ (overline@(B * open-interval@(0, R))))@(R ^ (alpha _ 1) * cdots * R ^ (alpha _ d) * d * absolute-value@(mu) * x)
absent less= (2 * pi) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * (integral _ (overline@(B * open-interval@(0, R))))@(R ^ (alpha _ 1) * cdots * R ^ (alpha _ d) * d * absolute-value@(mu) * x)
absent = (2 * pi * R) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * (integral _ (overline@(B * open-interval@(0, R))))@(d * absolute-value@(mu) * x)
absent = (2 * pi * R) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * (integral _ (overline@(B * open-interval@(0, R))))@(d * absolute-value@(mu) * x)
absent = (2 * pi * R) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * (integral _ (R ^ d))@(d * absolute-value@(mu) * x)
absent = (2 * pi * R) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * (integral _ (R ^ d))@(d * absolute-value@(mu) * x)
absent = (2 * pi * R) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * norm@(mu)
absent = (2 * pi * R) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * norm@(mu)

para.p: Then using (),

Math.text: (norm@(F * (- 2 * pi * i * x) ^ alpha * mu)) _ infinity less= norm@((- 2 * pi * i * x) ^ alpha * mu) less= (2 * pi * R) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * norm@(mu)

para.p:
But we have already established that
=
⁢
D α
^ μ
⁢ F
(
⁢
(
-
⁢ 2 π i x
)
α
μ
)
, which with the above inequality completes the proof. ∎

For an open subset
Ω
of
R d
, we denote by
⁢ D
( Ω )
the set of those
∈ ϕ
⁢
C ∞
( Ω )
such that
⁢ supp ϕ
is a compact set. Elements of
⁢ D
( Ω )
are called test functions.

It is a fact that there is a test function
ϕ
satisfying: (i)
=
⁢ ϕ
( x )
1
for
≤
| x |
1
, (ii)
=
⁢ ϕ
( x )
0
for
≥
| x |
2
, (iii)
0 ≤ ϕ ≤ 1
, and (iv)
ϕ
is radial. We write, for
= k
1 , 2 , …
,

Math.text: formulae@(phi _ k * x = phi * k ^ (- 1) * x, x element-of R ^ d)

para.p:
For any multi-index
α
,

Math.text: formulae@(D ^ alpha * phi _ k * x = k ^ (- (absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * D ^ alpha * phi * k ^ (- 1) * x, x element-of R ^ d)

para.p: hence

Math.text: (norm@(D ^ alpha * phi _ k)) _ infinity = k ^ (- (absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * (norm@(D ^ alpha * phi)) _ infinity

para.p: We use the following lemma to prove the theorem that comes after it. 3 3 footnote 3 Thomas H. Wolff, Lectures on Harmonic Analysis, p. 4, Lemma 1.5.

p.text:
Suppose that
∈ f
⁢

(

and

⁢

f
⁢

(

for each
≤

N

≤
| α |
N
,
→
⁢
D α
(
⁢
ϕ k
f
)
⁢
D α
f
in
⁢
L 1
(
R d
)
as

.

para.p:
Let
≤
| α |
N
. In the case
= α 0
,

Math.text: (norm@(phi _ k * f - f)) _ 1 = (integral _ (R ^ d))@(absolute-value@(phi _ k * x * f * x - f * x) * differential-d@(x))
(norm@(phi _ k * f - f)) _ 1
absent = (integral _ (R ^ d))@(absolute-value@(phi _ k * x * f * x - f * x) * differential-d@(x))
absent = (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) >= k))@(absolute-value@(phi _ k * x * f * x - f * x) * differential-d@(x))
absent = (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) >= k))@(absolute-value@(phi _ k * x * f * x - f * x) * differential-d@(x))
absent less= (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) >= k))@(absolute-value@(f * x) * differential-d@(x))
absent less= (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) >= k))@(absolute-value@(f * x) * differential-d@(x))

para.p:
Because
∈ f
⁢

(

0
as

Suppose that
> α 0
. The Leibniz rule tells us that with
=
c β
(
α β
)
, we have, for each
k
,

Math.text: D ^ alpha * phi _ k * f = phi _ k * D ^ alpha * f + (sum _ (0 less beta less= alpha))@(c _ beta * D ^ (alpha - beta) * f * D ^ beta * phi _ k)

para.p:
For
=
C 1
max β
|
c β
|
,

Math.text: (norm@(D ^ alpha * phi _ k * f - phi _ k * D ^ alpha * f)) _ 1 less= (sum _ (0 less beta less= alpha))@((norm@(c _ beta * D ^ (alpha - beta) * f * D ^ beta * phi _ k)) _ 1)
(norm@(D ^ alpha * phi _ k * f - phi _ k * D ^ alpha * f)) _ 1
absent less= (sum _ (0 less beta less= alpha))@((norm@(c _ beta * D ^ (alpha - beta) * f * D ^ beta * phi _ k)) _ 1)
absent less= C _ 1 * (sum _ (0 less beta less= alpha))@((norm@(D ^ beta * phi _ k)) _ infinity * (norm@(D ^ (alpha - beta) * f)) _ 1)
absent less= C _ 1 * (sum _ (0 less beta less= alpha))@((norm@(D ^ beta * phi _ k)) _ infinity * (norm@(D ^ (alpha - beta) * f)) _ 1)

para.p:
Let
=
C 2
max
0 < β ≤ α
∥
⁢
D β
ϕ
∥
∞
. By (), for
0 < β ≤ α
we have

Math.text: (norm@(D ^ beta * phi _ k)) _ infinity = k ^ (- (absolute-value@(beta)) _ 1) * (norm@(D ^ beta * phi)) _ infinity less= C _ 2 * k ^ (- (absolute-value@(beta)) _ 1) less= C _ 2 * k ^ (- 1)

para.p: Thus

Math.text: (norm@(D ^ alpha * phi _ k * f - phi _ k * D ^ alpha * f)) _ 1 less= C _ 1 * C _ 2 * k ^ (- 1) * (sum _ (0 less beta less= alpha))@((norm@(D ^ (alpha - beta) * f)) _ 1)

para.p:
which tends to
0
as
→ k ∞
. For any
k
,

Math.text: (norm@(phi _ k * D ^ alpha * f - D ^ alpha * f)) _ 1 = (integral _ (R ^ d))@(absolute-value@(phi _ k * x * D ^ alpha * f * x - D ^ alpha * f * x) * differential-d@(x))
(norm@(phi _ k * D ^ alpha * f - D ^ alpha * f)) _ 1
absent = (integral _ (R ^ d))@(absolute-value@(phi _ k * x * D ^ alpha * f * x - D ^ alpha * f * x) * differential-d@(x))
absent = (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) >= k))@(absolute-value@(phi _ k * x * D ^ alpha * f * x - D ^ alpha * f * x) * differential-d@(x))
absent = (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) >= k))@(absolute-value@(phi _ k * x * D ^ alpha * f * x - D ^ alpha * f * x) * differential-d@(x))
absent less= (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) >= k))@(absolute-value@(D ^ alpha * f * x) * differential-d@(x))
absent less= (integral _ (absolute-value@(x) >= k))@(absolute-value@(D ^ alpha * f * x) * differential-d@(x))

para.p:
and because
∈
⁢
D α
f
⁢
L 1
(
R d
)
, this tends to
0
as
→ k ∞
. But

Math.text: (norm@(D ^ alpha * phi _ k * f - D ^ alpha * f)) _ 1 less= (norm@(D ^ alpha * phi _ k * f - phi _ k * D ^ alpha * f)) _ 1 + (norm@(phi _ k * D ^ alpha * f - D ^ alpha * f)) _ 1

para.p: which completes the proof. ∎

Now we calculate the Fourier transform of the derivative of a function, and show that the smoother a function is the faster its Fourier transform decays. 4 4 footnote 4 Thomas H. Wolff, Lectures on Harmonic Analysis, p. 4, Proposition 1.4.

p.text:
If
∈ f
⁢
C N
(
R d
)
and
∈
⁢
D α
f
⁢
L 1
(
R d
)
for each
≤
| α |
N
, then for each
≤
| α |
N
,

Math.text: formulae@(widehat@(D ^ alpha * f) * xi = (2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha * hat@(f) * xi, xi element-of R ^ d)

p.text:
There is a constant
= C
⁢ C
( f , N )
such that

Math.text: formulae@(absolute-value@(hat@(f) * xi) less= C * (1 + absolute-value@(xi)) ^ (- N), xi element-of R ^ d)

para.p:
If
∈ g
⁢
C 1
c
(
R d
)
, then for any
1 ≤ j ≤ d
, integrating by parts,

Math.text: (integral _ (R ^ d))@((partial-differential _ j)@(g) * x * e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * xi) cdot x) * differential-d@(x)) = 2 * pi * i * xi _ j * (integral _ (R ^ d))@(g * x * e ^ (- (2 * pi * i * xi) cdot x) * differential-d@(x))

para.p:
It follows by induction that if
∈ g

C N

N

Math.text: formulae@(widehat@(D ^ alpha * g) * xi = (2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha * hat@(g) * xi, xi element-of R ^ d)

para.p:
Let
≤

N

f k

f

we have

Math.text: formulae@(widehat@(D ^ alpha * f _ k) * xi = (2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha * widehat@(f _ k) * xi, xi element-of R ^ d)

para.p: On the one hand,

Math.text: (norm@(widehat@(D ^ alpha * f _ k) - widehat@(D ^ alpha * f))) _ infinity = (norm@(F * (D ^ alpha * f _ k - D ^ alpha * f))) _ infinity less= (norm@(D ^ alpha * f _ k - D ^ alpha * f)) _ 1

para.p:
and Lemma tells us that this tends to
0
as
→ k ∞
. On the other hand, for
∈ ξ
R d
,

Math.text: absolute-value@(widehat@(D ^ alpha * f _ k) * xi - (2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha * hat@(f) * xi) = absolute-value@((2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha * widehat@(f _ k) * xi - (2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha * hat@(f) * xi)
absolute-value@(widehat@(D ^ alpha * f _ k) * xi - (2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha * hat@(f) * xi)
absent = absolute-value@((2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha * widehat@(f _ k) * xi - (2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha * hat@(f) * xi)
absent = absolute-value@((2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha) * absolute-value@(F * (f _ k - f) * xi)
absent = absolute-value@((2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha) * absolute-value@(F * (f _ k - f) * xi)
absent less= absolute-value@((2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha) * (norm@(f _ k - f)) _ 1
absent less= absolute-value@((2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha) * (norm@(f _ k - f)) _ 1

para.p:
which by Lemma tends to
0
as
→ k ∞
. Therefore, for
∈ ξ
R d
,

Math.text: absolute-value@(widehat@(D ^ alpha * f) * xi - (2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha * hat@(f) * xi) less= (norm@(widehat@(D ^ alpha * f _ k) - widehat@(D ^ alpha * f))) _ infinity + absolute-value@(widehat@(D ^ alpha * f _ k) * xi - (2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha * hat@(f) * xi)

para.p:
and because the right-hand side tends to
0
as
→ k ∞
, we get

Math.text: widehat@(D ^ alpha * f) * xi = (2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha * hat@(f) * xi

para.p:
If
∈ y
S

0
, from which we get

Math.text: (sum _ ((absolute-value@(beta)) _ 1 = N))@(absolute-value@(y ^ beta)) > 0

para.p:
The function
↦ y

N

R

such that

Math.text: formulae@(1 / C _ N less= (sum _ ((absolute-value@(beta)) _ 1 = N))@(absolute-value@(y ^ beta)), y element-of S ^ (d - 1))

para.p:
For nonzero
∈ x
R d
, write
= x
⁢
| x |
y
, with which
=
∑
=

N

⁢

N

. Therefore

Math.text: formulae@((absolute-value@(x)) ^ N less= C _ N * (sum _ ((absolute-value@(beta)) _ 1 = N))@(absolute-value@(x ^ beta)), x element-of R ^ d)

para.p:
For
≤
| α |
N
, because the Fourier transform of an element of
L 1
belongs to
C 0
, we have by () that
↦ ξ
⁢

^ f
( ξ )
belongs to
⁢

(

, and in particular is bounded. Then for
∈ ξ

Math.text: (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ N * absolute-value@(hat@(f) * xi) less= C _ N * (sum _ ((absolute-value@(beta)) _ 1 = N))@(absolute-value@(xi ^ beta) * absolute-value@(hat@(f) * xi))
(absolute-value@(xi)) ^ N * absolute-value@(hat@(f) * xi)
absent less= C _ N * (sum _ ((absolute-value@(beta)) _ 1 = N))@(absolute-value@(xi ^ beta) * absolute-value@(hat@(f) * xi))
absent = C _ N * (sum _ ((absolute-value@(beta)) _ 1 = N))@(absolute-value@(xi ^ beta * hat@(f) * xi))
absent = C _ N * (sum _ ((absolute-value@(beta)) _ 1 = N))@(absolute-value@(xi ^ beta * hat@(f) * xi))
absent less= C _ N * (sum _ ((absolute-value@(beta)) _ 1 = N))@((norm@(xi ^ beta * hat@(f) * xi)) _ infinity)
absent less= C _ N * (sum _ ((absolute-value@(beta)) _ 1 = N))@((norm@(xi ^ beta * hat@(f) * xi)) _ infinity)
absent = C ^ prime
absent = C ^ prime

para.p:
On the one hand, for
≥
| ξ |
1
we have

Math.text: 1 + absolute-value@(xi) less= 2 * absolute-value@(xi)

para.p: hence

Math.text: (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ (- N) less= ((1 + absolute-value@(xi)) / 2) ^ (- N) = 2 ^ N * (1 + absolute-value@(xi)) ^ (- N)

para.p: giving

Math.text: absolute-value@(hat@(f) * xi) less= C ^ prime * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ (- N) less= C ^ prime * 2 ^ N * (1 + absolute-value@(xi)) ^ (- N)

para.p:
On the other hand, for
≤
| ξ |
1
we have

Math.text: 1 + absolute-value@(xi) less= 2

para.p: and so

Math.text: absolute-value@(hat@(f) * xi) less= (norm@(hat@(f))) _ infinity * 2 ^ N * 2 ^ (- N) less= (norm@(hat@(f))) _ infinity * 2 ^ N * (1 + absolute-value@(xi)) ^ (- N)

para.p: Thus, for

Math.text: C = maximum@(2 ^ N * C ^ prime, 2 ^ N * (norm@(hat@(f))) _ infinity)

para.p: we have

Math.text: formulae@(absolute-value@(hat@(f) * xi) less= C * (1 + absolute-value@(xi)) ^ (- N), xi element-of R ^ d)

para.p: completing the proof. ∎

For a Borel measurable function
: f
→

para.p: By Parseval’s identity,

Math.text: (norm@(D ^ alpha * f _ 0)) _ 2 = (norm@((- 2 * pi * i * xi) ^ alpha * hat@(f) * (- xi))) _ 2
(norm@(D ^ alpha * f _ 0)) _ 2

absent = (2 * pi * R) ^ ((absolute-value@(alpha)) _ 1) * (norm@(f)) _ 2

para.p: proving the claim. ∎

Nikolsky’s inequality tells us that if the Fourier transform of a function is supported on a ball centered at the origin, then for
1 ≤ p ≤ q ≤ ∞
, the
L q
norm of the function is bounded above in terms of its
L p
norm. 7 7 footnote 7 Camil Muscalu and Wilhelm Schlag, Classical and Multilinear Harmonic Analysis, volume I, p. 83, Lemma 4.13.

(norm@(f)) _ q less= C _ d * R ^ (d * (1 / p - 1 / q)) * (norm@(f)) _ p

para.p: Moreover,

Math.text: (norm@(g)) _ a = ((integral _ (R ^ d))@((absolute-value@(R ^ (- d) * f * R ^ (- 1) * x)) ^ a * differential-d@(x))) ^ (1 / a)
(norm@(g)) _ a
absent = ((integral _ (R ^ d))@((absolute-value@(R ^ (- d) * f * R ^ (- 1) * x)) ^ a * differential-d@(x))) ^ (1 / a)
absent = ((integral _ (R ^ d))@(R ^ ((- d * a) + d) * (absolute-value@(f * y)) ^ a * differential-d@(y))) ^ (1 / a)
absent = ((integral _ (R ^ d))@(R ^ ((- d * a) + d) * (absolute-value@(f * y)) ^ a * differential-d@(y))) ^ (1 / a)
absent = R ^ (d * (1 / a - 1)) * (norm@(f)) _ a
absent = R ^ (d * (1 / a - 1)) * (norm@(f)) _ a

para.p: so () tells us

Math.text: R ^ (d * (1 / q - 1)) * (norm@(f)) _ q less= (norm@(hat@(chi))) _ r * R ^ (d * (1 / p - 1)) * (norm@(f)) _ p

para.p: i.e.

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ q less= (norm@(hat@(chi))) _ r * R ^ (d * (1 / p - 1 / q)) * (norm@(f)) _ p

para.p: Thus with

Math.text: C _ d = maximum@((norm@(hat@(chi))) _ 1, (norm@(hat@(chi))) _ infinity)

para.p: we have proved the claim. ∎

section.title: 5The Dirichlet kernel and Fejér kernel for R

para.p:
The function
∈
D M
⁢
C 0
( R )
defined by

Math.text: formulae@(D _ M * x = sine@(2 * pi * M * x) / (pi * x), x not-equals 0)

para.p:
and
=
⁢
D M
( 0 )
⁢ 2 M
, is called the Dirichlet kernel. Let
χ M
be the indicator function for the set
[
- M
, M ]
. We have, for
≠ x 0
,

Math.text: widehat@(chi _ R) * x = (integral _ R)@(chi _ R * xi * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * xi) * differential-d@(xi))
widehat@(chi _ R) * x
absent = (integral _ R)@(chi _ R * xi * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * xi) * differential-d@(xi))
absent = ((integral _ (- M)) ^ M)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * xi) * differential-d@(xi))
absent = ((integral _ (- M)) ^ M)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * xi) * differential-d@(xi))
absent = evaluated-at@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * xi) / (- 2 * pi * i * x), - M, M)
absent = evaluated-at@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * xi) / (- 2 * pi * i * x), - M, M)
absent = e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * M * x) / (- 2 * pi * i * x) + e ^ (2 * pi * i * M * x) / (2 * pi * i * x)
absent = e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * M * x) / (- 2 * pi * i * x) + e ^ (2 * pi * i * M * x) / (2 * pi * i * x)
absent = sine@(2 * pi * M * x) / (pi * x)
absent = sine@(2 * pi * M * x) / (pi * x)

para.p:
For
= x 0
,
⁢
^
χ R
( 0 )
=

=
⁢

. Thus,

Math.text: D _ M = widehat@(chi _ R)

For
∈ f
⁢

( R )
and
> M 0
, we define

Math.text: formulae@(S _ M * f * x = ((integral _ (- M)) ^ M)@(hat@(f) * xi * e ^ (2 * pi * i * xi * x) * differential-d@(xi)), x element-of R)

para.p: It is straightforward to check that

Math.text: formulae@(S _ M * f * x = (integral _ R)@((sine@(2 * pi * M * t) / (pi * t)) * f * (x - t) * differential-d@(t)) = D _ M * f * x, x element-of R)

para.p:
For
∈ f
⁢
L 1
( R )
,
> M 0
, and
∈ x R
,

Math.text: (1 / M) * ((integral _ 0) ^ M)@(S _ m * f * x * differential-d@(m)) = (1 / M) * ((integral _ 0) ^ M)@(((integral _ (- m)) ^ m)@(hat@(f) * xi * e ^ (2 * pi * i * xi * x) * differential-d@(xi)) * differential-d@(m))
(1 / M) * ((integral _ 0) ^ M)@(S _ m * f * x * differential-d@(m))
absent = (1 / M) * ((integral _ 0) ^ M)@(((integral _ (- m)) ^ m)@(hat@(f) * xi * e ^ (2 * pi * i * xi * x) * differential-d@(xi)) * differential-d@(m))

absent = (1 / M) * ((integral _ 0) ^ M)@(((integral _ (- m)) ^ m)@((integral _ R)@(f * y * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi * y) * differential-d@(y)) * e ^ (2 * pi * i * xi * x) * differential-d@(xi)) * differential-d@(m))

absent = (1 / M) * ((integral _ 0) ^ M)@(((integral _ (- m)) ^ m)@((integral _ R)@(f * y * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi * y) * differential-d@(y)) * e ^ (2 * pi * i * xi * x) * differential-d@(xi)) * differential-d@(m))
absent = (1 / M) * (integral _ R)@(f * y * ((integral _ 0) ^ M)@(((integral _ (- m)) ^ m)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi * (y - x)) * differential-d@(xi)) * differential-d@(m)) * differential-d@(y))
absent = (1 / M) * (integral _ R)@(f * y * ((integral _ 0) ^ M)@(((integral _ (- m)) ^ m)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi * (y - x)) * differential-d@(xi)) * differential-d@(m)) * differential-d@(y))
absent = (1 / M) * (integral _ R)@(f * y * ((integral _ 0) ^ M)@(D _ m * (y - x) * differential-d@(m)) * differential-d@(y))
absent = (1 / M) * (integral _ R)@(f * y * ((integral _ 0) ^ M)@(D _ m * (y - x) * differential-d@(m)) * differential-d@(y))
absent = (1 / M) * (integral _ R)@(f * y * ((integral _ 0) ^ M)@(((sine@(2 * pi * m) * (y - x)) / (pi * (y - x))) * differential-d@(m)) * differential-d@(y))
absent = (1 / M) * (integral _ R)@(f * y * ((integral _ 0) ^ M)@(((sine@(2 * pi * m) * (y - x)) / (pi * (y - x))) * differential-d@(m)) * differential-d@(y))
absent = (1 / M) * (integral _ R)@(f * y * (- evaluated-at@((cosine@(2 * pi * m) * (y - x)) / (2 * pi ^ 2 * (y - x) ^ 2), 0, M)) * differential-d@(y))
absent = (1 / M) * (integral _ R)@(f * y * (- evaluated-at@((cosine@(2 * pi * m) * (y - x)) / (2 * pi ^ 2 * (y - x) ^ 2), 0, M)) * differential-d@(y))
absent = (1 / M) * (integral _ R)@(f * y * (1 / (2 * pi ^ 2 * (y - x) ^ 2) - (cosine@(2 * pi * M) * (y - x)) / (2 * pi ^ 2 * (y - x) ^ 2)) * differential-d@(y))
absent = (1 / M) * (integral _ R)@(f * y * (1 / (2 * pi ^ 2 * (y - x) ^ 2) - (cosine@(2 * pi * M) * (y - x)) / (2 * pi ^ 2 * (y - x) ^ 2)) * differential-d@(y))

We define the Fejér kernel

and

⁢
K M

M
. Thus, because
K M
is an even function,

Math.text: (1 / M) * ((integral _ 0) ^ M)@(S _ m * f * x * differential-d@(m)) = K _ M * f * x

One proves that
K M
is an approximate identity:
≥
K M
0
,

para.p:
and for any
> δ 0

Math.text: (limit _ (M to infinity))@((integral _ (absolute-value@(x) > delta))@(K _ M * x * differential-d@(x))) = 0

The fact that

∈ f

*

.

We shall use the Fejér kernel to prove Bernstein’s inequality for
R
. 8 8 footnote 8 Mark A. Pinsky, Introduction to Fourier Analysis and Wavelets, p. 122, Theorem 2.3.17.

p.text:
If
∈ μ
⁢ M
( R )
,
> M 0
, and

Math.text: supp * mu subset-of closed-interval@(- M, M)
(norm@((hat@(mu)) ^ prime)) _ infinity less= 4 * pi * M * (norm@(hat@(mu))) _ infinity

para.p:
For
∈
x 0
R
, let
=
⁢ d
μ
x 0
( t )
⁢
e
-
⁢ 2 π i
x 0
t
d μ
( t )
.
μ
x 0
has the same support has
μ
, and

Math.text: widehat@(mu _ x _ 0) * x = (integral _ R)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * t) * differential-d@(mu _ x _ 0) * t) = (integral _ R)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * t) * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x _ 0 * t) * differential-d@(mu) * t) = hat@(mu) * (x + x _ 0)

para.p:
It follows that to prove the claim it suffices to prove that
≤
|
⁢
^ μ
′
( 0 )

⁢ 4 π M

.

Write
f =
^ μ
∈
⁢
C u
( R )
. Define
∈
Δ M
⁢
C c
( R )
by

Math.text: formulae@(Delta _ M * t = cases@(M - absolute-value@(t), absolute-value@(t) less M, 0, absolute-value@(t) >= M), t element-of R)

para.p:
We calculate, for
≠ x 0
,

Math.text: (integral _ R)@(Delta _ M * t * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * t) * differential-d@(t)) = - (e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * M * x) * ((- 1) + e ^ (2 * pi * i * M * x)) ^ 2) / (4 * pi ^ 2 * x ^ 2)
(integral _ R)@(Delta _ M * t * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * t) * differential-d@(t))
absent = (sine@(pi * M * x)) ^ 2 / (pi ^ 2 * x ^ 2)
absent = (sine@(pi * M * x)) ^ 2 / (pi ^ 2 * x ^ 2)
absent = (1 - cosine@(2 * pi * M * x)) / (2 * pi ^ 2 * x ^ 2)
absent = (1 - cosine@(2 * pi * M * x)) / (2 * pi ^ 2 * x ^ 2)

para.p: so

Math.text: widehat@(Delta _ M) * x = M * K _ M * x

para.p:
Then for
∈ t
[
- M
, M ]
,

Math.text: (integral _ R)@((e ^ (2 * pi * i * M * xi) - e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * M * xi)) * K _ M * xi * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi * t) * differential-d@(xi)) = widehat@(K _ M) * (t - M) - widehat@(K _ M) * (t + M)
(integral _ R)@((e ^ (2 * pi * i * M * xi) - e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * M * xi)) * K _ M * xi * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi * t) * differential-d@(xi))
absent = widehat@(K _ M) * (t - M) - widehat@(K _ M) * (t + M)
absent = (Delta _ M * ((- t) + M) - Delta _ M * (- t - M)) / M
absent = (Delta _ M * ((- t) + M) - Delta _ M * (- t - M)) / M
absent = t / M
absent = t / M

para.p:
On the one hand, the integral of the left-hand side with respect to
μ
is

Math.tex: \begin{split}&\displaystyle\int_{\mathbb{R}}\int_{\mathbb{R}}(e^{2\pi iM\xi}-e% ^{-2\pi iM\xi})K_{M}(\xi)e^{-2\pi i\xi t}d\xi d\mu(t)\\ \displaystyle=&\displaystyle\int_{\mathbb{R}}(e^{2\pi iM\xi}-e^{-2\pi iM\xi})K% _{M}(\xi)f(\xi)d\xi.\end{split}
Math.text: (integral _ R)@((integral _ R)@((e ^ (2 * pi * i * M * xi) - e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * M * xi)) * K _ M * xi * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi * t) * differential-d@(xi) * differential-d@(mu) * t)) = (integral _ R)@((e ^ (2 * pi * i * M * xi) - e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * M * xi)) * K _ M * xi * f * xi * differential-d@(xi))

para.p:
On the other hand, the integral of the right-hand side with respect to
μ
is

Math.text: (integral _ R)@((t / M) * differential-d@(mu) * t) = (1 / (- 2 * pi * i * M)) * integral _ R - 2 * pi * i * t * d * mu * t
(integral _ R)@((t / M) * differential-d@(mu) * t)
absent = (1 / (- 2 * pi * i * M)) * integral _ R - 2 * pi * i * t * d * mu * t
absent = (1 / (- 2 * pi * i * M)) * F * (- 2 * pi * i * t) * mu * 0
absent = (1 / (- 2 * pi * i * M)) * F * (- 2 * pi * i * t) * mu * 0
absent = (1 / (- 2 * pi * i * M)) * f ^ prime * 0
absent = (1 / (- 2 * pi * i * M)) * f ^ prime * 0

para.p: Hence

Math.text: (1 / (- 2 * pi * i * M)) * f ^ prime * 0 = (integral _ R)@((e ^ (2 * pi * i * M * xi) - e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * M * xi)) * K _ M * xi * f * xi * differential-d@(xi))

para.p: giving

Math.text: absolute-value@(f ^ prime * 0) less= 4 * pi * M * (norm@(f)) _ infinity * (norm@(K _ M)) _ 1 = 4 * pi * M * (norm@(f)) _ infinity

para.p: proving the claim. ∎
